title: Boris Johnson loses election vote — unveils plan B
text:
LONDON — U.K. MPs have once again rejected a snap election — but Boris Johnson could still get the ballot he craves.

The prime minister on Monday evening failed to get the House of Commons to support his call for an election, his third unsuccessful attempt since taking office in July.

The latest defeat for Johnson came on the same day as EU leaders agreed to delay the Brexit deadline until January 31, removing the immediate threat that the U.K. would leave the bloc without a deal. The prime minister, who repeatedly promised to pull the country out by the previous deadline of October 31, now hopes to run on a platform that blames the U.K. parliament for blocking Brexit.

Just 299 of 650 MPs voted for the motion. Johnson needed a two-thirds majority to trigger an election through the Fixed-Term Parliaments Act. His move was blocked by opposition parties including Labour, which has ruled out voting for an election unless a no-deal Brexit is completely ruled out.

"It is frankly time for the leader of the opposition to move his rusty Trabant from the yellow box junction where it is currently blocking progress.” — Boris Johnson

“This house cannot any longer keep this country hostage,” the prime minister said after he lost the vote, and called on the public to “replace this dysfunctional parliament.”

Yet Johnson had Plan B ready in his back pocket.

He told MPs he will propose a short, one-off piece of legislation to trigger an election on December 12. The advantage of this route is that it requires just a simple majority of MPs to vote in favor of it, instead of two-thirds of the house.

A No. 10 Downing Street official said: “This is the way to get Brexit done so the country can move on.”

To pass the bill, Johnson will seek to work together with the Liberal Democrats and Scottish National Party, who have said they will back a December election now that Brexit has been delayed to January 31.

Stuck on the date

But there is still one major sticking point: the date.

The Lib Dems and SNP want the election to take place on December 9, while the prime minister has insisted on December 12. The pro-EU parties favor the earlier date because it leaves less time for the prime minister to push the deal he struck with EU leaders through parliament, thus pulling the U.K. out of the European Union.

It’s a difference of just three days — but it could sink Johnson’s fresh attempt to force an election.

According to a No 10 official, the thinking in Downing Street is that for an election to happen on December 9, parliament would have to be dissolved on November 1 — at the end of this week. The official said this was too short a time period in which to get the election bill through parliament, especially as the government also plans to pass a budget bill for Northern Ireland this week.

But Liberal Democrat leader Jo Swinson said her party had “already rejected” the December 12 proposal. “Boris Johnson claims he wants a general election, but he also claimed he wouldn’t prorogue parliament or put a border down the Irish Sea,” she said. “He could have supported our bill for a general election on December 9.”

If the Liberal Democrats refuse to back Johnson's election bill on Tuesday, that reduces the chances that it will succeed. But it doesn’t eliminate them completely.

The government needs 326 votes, and if it gets the entire Conservative Party and SNP’s backing, it will have 323 — meaning that just three Labour rebels or ex-Tory independents could see the bill pass.

One Labour MP, Kate Hoey, voted in favor of a snap election on Monday, alongside 18 independent MPs including ex-Tories Alistair Burt, David Gauke, Amber Rudd and Rory Stewart.

The SNP has refused to reveal its hand. Following Monday's vote, its Westminster leader Ian Blackford said his party required “an absolute cast-iron assurance” that Johnson would not bring back his Brexit deal before an election.

“We have a prime minister who will say anything, do anything to get his way.” — Jeremy Corbyn

Both the SNP and Liberal Democrats fear the deal being ratified before an election is held. They now publicly admit that there is no majority for a second Brexit referendum in this current parliament, and they fear that the Withdrawal Agreement Bill, which ratifies Johnson’s Brexit deal into U.K. law, could go through with the support of maverick Labour MPs. In a vote last week, the bill was approved with a majority of 30.

A No. 10 official said the government will not bring back the Withdrawal Agreement Bill while the election bill is going through parliament — which could give the SNP the assurance it needs to throw its weight behind a snap poll.

But if both the SNP and Liberal Democrats decide that Johnson can't be trusted to keep his promise, his election bid could once again fail.

A key risk for Johnson during the passage of the bill is that opposition MPs could attempt to extend voting rights to 16- and 17-year-olds or to EU citizens by amending the bill. It is not clear, however, whether those voters would make it onto the electoral register in time.

An election no one wants

“Nobody in this house relishes the idea of a general election,” the prime minister told the Commons ahead of the vote on Monday, insisting that he would rather deliver Brexit with a “blazing urgency.”

“I simply do not believe that this house is capable of delivering on the priorities of the people, whether that means Brexit or anything else,” he said. “It is frankly time for the leader of the opposition to move his rusty Trabant from the yellow box junction where it is currently blocking progress.”

Jeremy Corbyn replied that he didn’t trust the prime minister — and neither did voters. “We have a prime minister who will say anything, do anything to get his way,” he said. “He will avoid his responsibilities, break his promises to dodge scrutiny.”

Corbyn accused Johnson of trying to suppress voter turnout by forcing a poll in the depths of winter. “In parts of this country it will be dark before 4 p.m.,” he said, adding that students will have gone home for their Christmas holidays. “No general election has been held in December since 1923.”

After Johnson announced that he would put a general election bill to a vote on Tuesday, Corbyn said that Labour would “obviously look and scrutinize that bill.”

But it may turn out to be a decision that is out of his party's hands.
